photo.description: Red Fort (Lal Qila). Delhi, India. The Red Fort also known as Lal Qil'ah or Lal Qila was the palace for Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan's new capital, Shahjahanabad, the seventh Muslim city in the Delhi site. He moved his capital from Agra in a move designed to bring prestige to his reign, and to provide ample opportunity to apply his ambitious building schemes and interests. The Red Fort stands at the eastern edge of Shahjahanabad, and gets its name from the massive wall of red sandstone that defines its four sides. The wall is 2.5 km long, and varies in height from 16m on the river side to 33 m towards the city. Measurements have shown that the plan was generated using a square grid of 82 m. The fort lies along the Yamuna River, which fed the moats that surround most of the wall. The wall at its north-eastern corner is adjacent to an older fort, the Salimgarh, a defense built by Islam Shah Sur in 1546. On 11 March 1783 Sikhs entered Red fort in Delhi and occupied the Diwan-i-Am. This task was carried out under the command of the Sardar Baghel Singh Dhaliwal of the Karor Singhia misl. (Sardar Baghel Singh Dhaliwal patrolling with men from his misl.) The Red Fort was conceived as a whole, and subsequent modifications have not taken away from the overall unity of the scheme. In the 18th century, however, occupiers and looters damaged some sections of the palace. After the Sepoy Mutiny of 1857, when the Fort was used as a headquarters, the British army occupied and destroyed many of its pavilions and gardens. A program for restoring the surviving parts of the fort began in 1903. The Red Fort is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Delhi, attracting millions of visitors every year. The fort is also the site from which the Prime Minister of India addresses the nation on August 15, 1947, the day India achieved independence from the United Kingdom.
photo.tags: india delhi fort индия дели red green gate wall spring flag
photo.title: Red Fort

The fort is also the site from which the Prime Minister of India addresses the nation on August 15, 1947, the day India achieved independence from the United Kingdom.

photo.description: Built between 1638 and 1648 by Mughal Emperor Shahjahan, the Red Fort was the residence of the dynasty until its end in 1857. This impressive gate was built by Shahjahan's son, Aurangzeb (1658-1707).

photo.title: Main Gate of the Red Fort
